properties.name: Ah Tee Ko Ko Mee
properties.description:
Address:
#01-100 Gourmet Street, Blk 27 Kelantan Court, 200027

Opening Hours:
Mon-Sat, 5.30am-1.30pm

Shop Recommendations:
Teochew Fishball Noodle

Other Details:
Sim Ah Tee, 73, is a hawker for over 50 years Being unable to read or write, Ah Tee was at a disadvantage when the Covid-19 Circuit Breaker started last year. While eateries and hawkers scrambled to offer food delivery, Ah Tee could not keep up with the new technology. “At the age of 70 plus, he’s not agile enough to multitask anymore. He’s still using the old Nokia handphone,” his son Calvin Sim, 49, tells 8days.sg. It doesn’t help that Ah Tee (pictured above) also faces competition from the bigger, more well-known Berseh Food Centre nearby. Despite the slow business, he has continued to open his stall as usual. “He’s a committed person. He’s making a loss every day, but insisted on carrying on till now despite using his own savings [to sustain]. As I’m working, I can’t manage his calls for him,” says Calvin, who tried to help his dad drum up business by posting about the stall on Facebook foodie groups like Can Eat! Hawker Food.

Contributor:
8 Days

properties.name: 85 乡村古早蚝煎
properties.description:
Address:
#01-05, 85 Fengshan Centre, Blk 85 Bedok North St 4, 460085

Opening Hours:
daily 11.30am-11pm.

Shop Recommendations:
Carrot cake

Other Details:
Like Ah Tee, hawker Goh Peng Huan, 61, struggles with dismal numbers. Together with his partner Anne Tan, 59, he runs the 85 乡村古早蚝煎 stall at Fengshan Centre in Bedok selling fried oyster omelette, carrot cake, bak chor mee and handmade ngoh hiang till 11pm daily. From February to June last year, they had zero income as their hawker centre was undergoing renovations, which were delayed by the pandemic. When Phase 2 (HA) kicked in on May 14, 2021, there was immediately a “drastic drop” in business. Speaking to 8days.sg, Peng Huan’s daughter Desrina Goh, 39, says: “There was a 60 per cent drop in customers. Today was the worst yet, not even 30 per cent of the usual number of customers.” Delivery is also out of the question for Peng Huan. “My dad is illiterate, so it’s very difficult for him to work with a digital delivery platform. WhatsApp orders are not possible as well, because he can’t read,” Desrina frets.

properties.description:
Address:
AMK Ave 10, Cheng San Food Centre, Everyday Tea Stall, 天天茶室 #01-128 560527

Opening Hours:
Open 5.30am - 1030am Tues - Thu, Sat & Sun until 11.30am. Rest days Mon & Fri.

Shop Recommendations:


Other Details:
Stall has been operating since the 1979s. 50 years of fragrant hand-brewed traditional coffee and tea from $0.80/cup – The owner insists on keeping prices low (they were planning to +$0.10/cup in June but Covid hit and he decided not to) due to the owner’s belief that “[they] have seen 3 generation of customers from grandfathers to their grandchildren, and keeping prices low is a way of repaying the favour to our loyal customers. As long as they like the coffee, [he will] continue to brew it”. True to his words, the price of their drinks have only risen by $0.20 over the past 12 years.

properties.name: Ah Seng (Hai Nam) Coffee
properties.description:
Address:
Amoy Street Food Centre #02-95 69111

Opening Hours:


Shop Recommendations:


Other Details:
This is one coffee stall I used to frequent on weekends and they enjoyed brisk business from CBD crowd or weekend cyclist in the past. But due to phase 2, their business is so bad. You might wonder, how bad can it be? I went at 11am to order 4 French toast, 2 Kaya toast,5 packets of kopi and teh and 2 soft boiled eggs for about $15. They told me I’m the 2nd or 3rd customer since 6am and others only bought one or two cups of kopi. Which means they only earned probably about $20 since 6am������ Their pricing is already relatively lower than other coffee stalls so it doesn’t make sense for them to be on any delivery platform. Please please don’t let our local coffee heritage die. That one cup of $8 latte you save today can be used here to save a local business. If you happen to be at the vicinty, please patronise this mother and son shop.

Contributor:
Cheryl Yap

properties.name: Yong Tau Foo (酿豆腐)
properties.description:
Address:
Blk 89 Circuit Road, #01-95 370089

Opening Hours:
daily 6am-2pm

Shop Recommendations:


Other Details:
Helping a friend who is badly affected by the Phase 2 Heightened Alert. They are neither on delivery platforms nor knows about Hawkers united until recently. This unassuming couple are up 3am every day, preparing fresh Yong Tau Foo for sale. They serve yummy versions such as the Dry (sweet sauce), Soupy and Laksa. Look at the variety and you know it is a hit with the elderly – who loves items such as brinjal, lady-finger, yam, pork belly, intestines and so forth. Their Laksa is very very old-school-authentic, too! Serene insisted to serve value for money Yong Tau Foo in the Macpherson community for the past 7 years. She refused to raise price even as supplies do get more expensive over the years. Always courteous, Steven serves his wok-hei Char Kway Teow at the back of the stall as supplement as the elderly loves it. The one and only Yong Tau Foo stall in this market. Pls support if you are in the area! P/S: Serene’s parents used to own this famous Yong Tau Foo stall in Kallang Airport for the past 30 years – 40 years and they decided to retire and pass down the family recipe!

properties.name: Moli Food Stall
properties.description:
Address:
16 Bedok South Road, #01-18 Singapore 460016

Opening Hours:


Shop Recommendations:
Vadai

Other Details:
Bedok Snack Stall Barely Gets Customers, Auntie Still Wakes Up Early To Make & Sell Vadais. I was walking around and observing that many stalks are doing brisk business (probably due to a wet and rainy Saturday) until I spotted this lone stall - there was no one in queue. I observed that maybe one or 2 folks would walk up to the stall, take a look and walk off. I do not know why. I decided to go up to the Aunty and strike up a conversation with her. Aunty is very soft spoken. She manage this stall on her own most times and sometimes with ad hoc help. She gets up early to prepare the ingredients. She / her stall is not on any delivery platform / FB. She told me her business is so bad that she hardly makes any money. If not for the one month rental rebate from G, she hardly makes any money after deducting all the ingredients and supplies etc. Her fear is understandable. So much so that she does not even dare to make more than 10 Vadai at a time for fear of them becoming too cold and hard which she is worried that it will make her lose her usual and maybe potential customers. I bought a few Vadai back to try and I must say at $0.60cents a piece, they are good. Soft and flavourful. I choose to support her which I really think she genuinely needed more support in letting people know her existence. As you are reading this, this is one such stall that you can seriously consider showing your support to her and by sharing this post. Not very expensive / difficult to begin with. What is genuinely needed here is more support, more sharing and awareness for her. Life is already very tough for her at the current situation and its getting more harder each day as she wonders how long she can keep going and sustain it.

properties.name: Meng Fruits
properties.description:
Address:
Block 4A Jalan Batu Market & Hawker Centre #01-32 432004

Opening Hours:


Shop Recommendations:


Other Details:
I decided to venture into Jln Batu Hawker Centre. As I was walking around, I noticed this lone figure sitting quietly staring at his mobile phone inside his stall. In my 5 minutes of observation, I noticed maybe 15 folks walked past his stall. Not a single one of them approach his stall. I decided to walk up to his stall. When Uncle saw me approaching him, he eagerly stand up and asked what I would like to have. I can sense his urgency but when he said, I am his 1st customer of the day. My heart sank deeply at that moment. The time then was 1145am, politely I asked if his sales takings were affected by the recent prohibition of dining in. He gave out a loud sigh.. I can sense his helplessness then and there. Jokingly he said "人算不如天算" (unpredictable situation). "Its a very tough situation". He relies on regulars and walk in customers. Now that it is the by default mode to WFH, his regulars don't come that frequently anymore. And walk in customers who can't dine in, are not buying drinks from him that much. Also, Jln Batu Hawker Centre can be a bit ulu to some. Regardless of the situation, Uncle still maintain his positive outlook. With a sense of pride, he strongly recommended to me his 100% handmade agar agar jelly dessert. He said his agar agar is probably the cheapest or if not, one of the cheapest that one can ever locate in Singapore. At 0.50cents a piece of the agar agar jelly, they come in various flavours. Coffee, Yam, Rainbow, plain and few others - really Can Eat for me. This is the best part - Uncle refused to increase his price over the years. He said his customers included mostly senior citizens and those who are staying around the area are in 1, 2 and 3 rooms flat. Affordability is an issue to some of the folks there. Uncle said he could not bear to increase his pricing and would rather earn lesser or none at times. Even when he is struggling to stay afloat, he still has a compassion heart for others. For this, he has my utmost respect. What surprises me was that Uncle is also selling his agar agar jelly in a big square plastic container box at only $4 - see picture. I got 3 boxes of Yam agar agar jelly without hesitation. Uncle was very appreciative and hope that I will come back soon to try his yakult fruit juices. He is also selling slice cut fruits too. Folks, this is one genuine Hawker whose business is greatly affected by the present situation. He has a big heart and filled with compassion. He deserve all your support, so please go down to support him and share this post for greater awareness. Whether its a slice of cut fruit or a piece of agar agar jelly at 0.50 cents or a cup of fruit juice, it matters alot to him.

properties.name: Malay stall
properties.description:
Address:
Blk 136 Potong Pasir Ave 1

Opening Hours:
6am to 2pm

Shop Recommendations:


Other Details:
Copied from FB post: Hi all, I'm a taxi driver. Everyday morning 4.15am, I will pick up a Malay aunty from teck whye to blk 136 potong pasir ave 1. This Malay aunty selling Malay foods at blk 136 potong pasir. She in her late 60s with walking difficulty . Walking with a walking stick. Due to this covid-19, her business is badly affected. She is old traditional style .Don trust food delivery like grabfood or foodpanda. I pick her up daily since 2018 till now. Due to covid19, her business hit badly. Sometime she have to owe my taxi fare accumulated near $100+. Knowing government giving subsidy for rental but the coffeeshop owner does not give them the rebate. Despite going to MP several time but still no action taken. She have a soft and kind heart. Always help those who she can help like, In potong pasir neighborhood, there a guy in his mid 40s with some mental issue, without failed, she will try to give him $2 and food few time almost everyday. Everyday during the journey, I will try to ask how her business the day before. Sometime she will say , business is quite bad till she can't pay her daily rental $50 etc. Her leftover food, she will try not to throw away. Sometime her balance kuey / curry puff she will ask someone to pass to the mosque. Sometime , she owe my taxi fare near $100+ , she will need to wait for her monthly CPF retirement fund to come in to pay me. Hope, people who nearby or staying at potong pasir will support her food. She sell Malay food like nasi lemak, mee Siam , Mee goreng , Mee rebus , Mee Soto and many more.
